div.p:
1. VII: Tuesday. There came to my Office this Morning three persons from Switzerland, who have the project of forming a settlement in the United States, to which they expect that some thousands of their countrymen will emigrate— They brought me a pamphlet containing their petition for a free grant of land, and certain privileges, and they say that the late Spanish Minister Onis promised them a grant of such extent as they should wish, and all encouragements possible, to induce them to settle in the Province of Texas— But not having heard from Mr Onis since his return to Spain, and preferring to settle in the United States they now apply for lands to Congress. They were desirous of seeing the President, and went from the Office to his house. But Congress will not probably give them Lands. The names of two of them were Dupasquier and Leuba. The name of the third I did not ascertain. Edward Wyer our Consul at Hamburg came and sat with me perhaps two hours, talking upon all sorts of subjects. He says Jonathan Russell is coming to Washington, and he hates him as much as ever— Mrs Adams had this Evening her usual weekly tea-party which was attended by about fifty persons— Among the company were Mr J. S. Skinner the Postmaster at Baltimore, and his wife. He is a man of mingled character—of daring and pernicious principles, or restless and rash temper, and yet of useful and honourable enterprize— Ruffian, Patriot and Philanthropist are so blended in him, that I cannot appretiate him without a mingled sentiment of detestation and esteem— I consider him as the originator and cause of all the Baltimore piracies, which have injured and still dishonour this Nation. He has infected not only that City, but the moral feeling of this whole community, and the public Councils of the Country, to such a degree as to stay the hand of Justice itself. He has embroiled us with two foreign Nations whose good-
will it is most important to us to possess— He has been now nearly two years under indictment for being concerned in the Baltimore piracies; and has contrived to get his father in law appointed the judge to decide upon them. Yet his private character is such that he has numerous and very ardent friends— He made to the Government at a critical period important disclosures concerning M’Gregor and his Amelia Island buccaneering expedition; and he has been during the last year Editor of a weekly newspaper called the American Farmer, devoted altogether to agricultural improvements, and which is a very valuable publication.— I conversed with him upon it and he told me that the next number would contain a Letter from Mr Pickering.

2. VII:J. M. Forbes called here this morning, and afterwards at the Office— He has some inclination for the appointment of Collector of the Port of Plymouth in Massachusetts, from which he says Henry Warren is to be removed as a defaulter, in his accounts— Among the vicissitudes of human affairs, the fate of that family of Warren is to me a source of melancholy and would it might be of useful reflection. Ambition and Pride have been their ruin— Their mother was a sister of James Otis, one of the fathers of the American Revolution— With no other advantages of education than those common to females of respectable families in the country part of New-England fourscore years ago, she had a mind capable of aspiring to the summit of literary fame— She has given herself to the world, and has challenged the notice of posterity, as a dramatic poetess and a historian of the American Revolution— In both cases she had formed a delusive estimate of her powers— Her two Tragedies are to criticism, what a bottled foetus is to natural history; curious conceptions but without an organization ever susceptible of receiving life— Even her fugitive poems, which in manuscript might have passed for proofs of mind beyond an ordinary level, became despicable in print, and a bound volume. Her History has higher though still feeble pretensions to merit. It was scarcely worth the waste of paper and type upon three octavo volumes; but it may hold its place upon the shelf with many other worthless Histories of that period. If a flying fish could fancy itself an Eagle it would make the same mistake of its nature and its element as Mrs Warren made of hers— Her husband was a man of some talents, but under the ascendancy of hers to his and her misfortune— They were ardent Patriots in our Revolution, and during my earliest infancy were the dearest and most intimate friends of my father and Mother. They had then five sons—James, Charles, Winslow, Henry and George, of whom the two youngest were very nearly of my age— They were five as handsome, well-bred and promising boys as ever kindled the hopes of a parent; and among the earliest and profoundest of my recollections are the constant and urgent admonitions of my dear mother to look to those children as my model and to imitate their deportment and manners— Yet everyone of them has turned out unfortunately— James entered the Navy at the beginning of our Revolution, and was saved from destruction by losing his leg in the battle by which the Serapis was taken. James was then a Lieutenant of Marines been in the frigate Alliance and has been ever since a helpless cripple, subsisting upon his pension, his Parents, and perhaps the Post-Office— Charles, the flower of the family, died of a consumption at twenty-two— Winslow, the victim of his own beauty; led a licentious and adventurous life, with the varying fortunes of a gamester, and the dissipations of an homme a bonnes fortunes the longing of prurient virgins, and the plaything of practised harlots, one day wallowing in profligate affluence, and another pining in the debtors dungeon, till driven by desperation at the age of thirty to enter the army as a lieutenant, he was killed by the Savages at the butchery of St. Clair’s defeat in November 1791— Henry has maintained for many years a more respectable standing in Society— Married to a very amiable woman, and has raised and well-educated a large family of children— But his life has not been regular; and he is now to be removed from a public office for malversation— George settled in the District of Maine, as a practicing lawyer— Was two or three years a member of the Massachusetts Legislature, but burnt out with early intemperance and died young— When the Constitution of Massachusetts was made in 1781. James Warren the father was chosen the first Lieutenant-Governor under it— But he declined accepting it, at the instigation of his wife, who persuaded him that he ought to have been chosen the Governor instead of Hancock— This was the turning of the tide of his Affairs— From that time he gradually lost his popularity and political influence; became a discontented and disaffected man—declined in fortune and reputation favoured Shays’s insurrection; courted in their last days Hancock, and Samuel Adams, turned against Washington’s Administration, and became inveterate against my father’s; and when Jefferson came in to power, the Post-Office and the Collectorship of Plymouth for James Warren junior and Henry were the rewards of the republicanism of the whole family— Mrs Warren published her History, and adopted it to the popular prejudices of the time, sacrificed all the antient friendships and social affections of her youth, to join in vulgar aspersions and venomous
imputations upon my father, and was paid by the Post-Office and the Collectorship for her sons. At the Commencement at Cambridge in 1817. Henry Warren had a son who graduated, and we were invited to the chamber where they entertained their friends. He there treated us with great civility— Some months since he wrote me a Letter, proposing to resign his office, upon condition that his son should be appointed in his place. I took his Letter to the President, but his Office being one of those depending upon the Treasury Department, I did not think proper to interfere with the disposal of it— And this is what I now told Forbes; who said he would speak to Mr Crawford himself, and observed that the delicacy which I practiced was not returned in the same way— I called at the President’s and asked his directions for answering the Letters of Governor Clark of Georgia— He said he had concluded to refer them and particularly the one charging the Indian Agent Mitchell to the Attorney-General for his opinion, in what manner the charges may best be investigated; and after that, it was his intention to put the papers into the hands of Mr Crawford, who was particularly friendly to Mitchell, and to whom it will be but candid to make the communication— The President said that his accusation had been brought against Mitchell last Winter by General Gaines; Mitchell had been here without authority or permission; to clear it up. The President said he himself had not been satisfied with Mitchell’s conduct, and in going into Georgia, had avoided seeing or being accompanied by him. He feared there was too much foundation for the charges against him in the Governor of Georgia’s Letter— Yet a full opportunity to justify himself should be given him, and the accusation of an Enemy ought not to be taken for granted. I told him I should then wait for his further directions— Evening at home; but without writing; and arrears of Journal still running up.

3. VI:30. I received on the 29th. of last Month a Letter from the French Minister Hyde de Neuville, a Letter upon the Baltimore Pirates, written in a tone which I could not stomach; containing a threat in general and ambiguous terms, that if we should not very soon take measures effectually to suppress them, France would authorize search by her naval Officers of suspected vessels sailing from our Ports— I took it yesterday to the President who was much incensed at it, and I read to him the draft of a Letter to him that I had made, asking an explanation of the passage containing the threat— The President approved it, but requested me to shew it, and also De Neuville’s Letter to the other members of the Administration— I took them this Morning to Mr Crawford at his Office— Crawford thought there were other passages of De Neuville’s Letter that ought to be noticed and resented; but ultimately approved my draft which I then sent to Mr Calhoun to read and pass to the other Heads of Departments. Mr Dana, the Senator from Connecticut, and Commodore Chauncey were at my Office— Dana has an old project for establishing a line of maritime jurisdiction. Chauncey recommended a person named Ladico, at Port Mahon to be U.S. Consul for the Balearic Islands. He had also claims for compensation for negotiating the last Treaty with the Dey of Algiers, and for having several of the Consuls to the Barbary Powers, at divers times on board his Squadron.— I had a company of Gentlemen this day to dinner. Mr Calhoun, Secretary at War, Messrs.R. M. Johnson, Mellen, Morril, Pinkney, Roberts and Van Dyke of the Senate, Bloomfield, Burton, Foot, Hemphill, Mercer, Metcalfe, James Parker, Simkins, Storrs, J. W. Taylor and Warfield, of the House of Representatives, and Joseph Jones Monroe the President’s brother— Mr Rufus King, Senator from New-York sent for excuse that he does not dine abroad. Mr Livermore, member of the House accepted but was unwell and did not come— Mrs Adams did not dine with us. The Company withdrew about nine.

4. VII:Mr Silsbee called at my House this Morning with Horace Gray, youngest Son of Mr William Gray of Boston. Mr Sanford also, one of the Senators from New-York was here.— His Colleague Mr R. King came and passed a couple of hours with me at my Office. He has been returned again to the Senate by the Legislature of New-York, in a manner which is unparalleled in this Union— The choice ought regularly to have been made this time last Winter; but there were three parties in the Legislature, of which that in favour of Mr King was the smallest. Governor Clinton’s influence was all exerted against him and the republican opposition to Clinton had a Candidate of their own— When the next house of Assembly were chosen, last May, it turned out that the federalists had gained
ground, which Clinton’s party had lost— He therefore to maintain himself found it indispensably necessary to conciliate the federalists, and besides appointing several of them to important Offices in the State he changed his policy towards Mr King, to such a degree, that in his Speech to the New-York Legislature he recommended King to their choice, not indeed by name, but designating him in terms not to be mistaken. The republican opposition took also the same direction, and King who after ten trials last Winter could not get so many as twenty votes out of 150. now came in by an unanimous vote of the Senate, and by all but three in the House of Assembly. Shortly before the Meeting of Congress, he published at the request of a Missouri-question Meeting at New-York, the substance of his two Speeches last Winter in the Senate on that Bill, which was then lost by the disagreement between the two Houses on the restricting clause— This publication has largely contributed to kindle the flame now raging throughout the Union, on that question, and which threatens its dissolution. King is strongly affected and agitated by it— Whether he sees the consequences in their full extent and has made up his mind to promote them, even to the separation of the Union I am not sure—but my own opinion is that no man ought to take an active part in that discussion without being first prepared for that . . . and reconciled to it; because it must end in that— Mrs Adams spent the Evening with the boys at her Sister Smith’s.

5. VII: This was the day of the annual Meeting of the Commissioners of the sinking fund; and the Meeting was held at eleven O’Clock, at one of the Committee Rooms of the Senate at the Capitol— The President of the Senate, Mr Gaillard, The Secretary of the Treasury, Crawford, and the Attorney General, Wirt were present—but Chief Justice Marshall was absent at Baltimore where his Son was married on Thursday Evening to Miss Alexander— The yearly Report of the Commissioners was read and signed, but the question which has lately been raised, by some of the holders of three per Cent Stock, who claimed by Law payment of their Stock at par, from the proceeds of the Sales of Public Lands, was postponed to another meeting at which the opinion of the Chief Justice might be obtained— The business of the Meeting was soon transacted and it adjourned. After being half an hour in the Senate Chamber; where I found Brown of Louisiana and Gaillard were for taking Texas, I went into the Hall of the House of Representatives, where they were in the heat of the Missouri debate— Daniel P. Cook was speaking in favour of the Restriction; and was followed by Mr Hemphill of Philadelphia, on the same side— After he had spoken about an hour and before he had finished, the house adjourned. Walking to my Office, Mr Henry Meigs, member of the House from New-York told me that he had offered this Morning several Resolutions, with a view to appropriate the proceeds of the public Lands to the emancipation of the Slaves, throughout the Union. This I suppose is to serve him as an apology to his Constituents, for voting against the restriction.— Johnson Hellen dined with us; and Mrs Adams with our Sons George and John spent the Evening at Mr Hyde de Neuville’s.

6. VI: At Six O’Clock this Morning, our Sons George and John departed in the Stage for Baltimore, returning to the University at Cambridge, where the term commences next Friday— The six weeks of vacation which they have spent with us here have been much enlivened by their company— There is nothing vicious in their morals, and nothing unamiable in their dispositions— George is of a slender, infirm Constitution, with symptoms of occasional illness, alarming to the . . .ight and affection of a Parent— John is more vigorous, though his childhood was yet more weakly than George’s. They have both Understandings, naturally good, but George’s turn is more to contemplation and study, and Johns to active life. The Powers of George’s mind are now unfolding themselves, and afford reasonable grounds for hope— John’s ambition is not yet excited beyond the standard of keeping pace with others. He is on a par with some of the best Scholars in his Class and has no ambition to outstrip them— George struggled sometime for the first place, but was overcome in competition, and gave up the contest in despair— He maintains a respectable station in his Class, and feels sufficiently the spur of emulation. He has some excentric habits, and some awkwardness in his deportment— This however could probably wear gradually away by intercourse with the world— I have introduced them while they have been here as much into company as I could and prevailed upon them both to dance, at the parties where there has been opportunity for it. There is a bashfulness in young persons, first coming into general Society very painful to themselves, and disadvantageous to their estimation with others, which their Parents and friends should assist them in throwing off. An easy but respectful and delicate familiarity with conversation with women is essential to the perfection of good-breeding; and nothing contributes so effectually to give it, as dancing— I never possessed it myself, because though taught to dance when a child, I did not till late in youth, break through the timidity which restrained me from dancing in company, and having no fund of Conversation adopted to the taste and feelings of the sex, I have always been reserved and cold in my intercourse with them. Conscious of
this defect in my own character, I would fain preserve my children from it, and perceiving at their first introduction into company here that their timidity withheld them from dancing and gave them an awkwardness of appearance not creditable to them, I urged and insisted upon their dancing, which they at first did with great reluctance, but before they left us, relished so highly that I trust no further instigation will be necessary to break them into the practice. My opinion is strongly favorable to the usefulness both physical and moral, of dancing, to young people of both sexes— My Sons have also had an opportunity of hearing the debates in both Houses of Congress during their visit here; another source of improvement which I was glad of providing for them. I hope their time here has not been lost; and that the blessing of God may attend them through life— I attended Church at the Capitol and heard a Mr Rice preach; said to be a man of reputation for pulpit eloquence, but not according to my estimation of the Art— The weather was warm, and the streets and roads so bad for walking that after returning from Church, I passed the remainder of the day at home— Missed visits from Mr Baldwin and Coll. Bomford.

7. VI:30.Coll. Morrison of Kentucky and Coll. Taylor of the State of Ohio, called to visit me at the Office— This Coll James Taylor is the person who in the Winter of 1807–8 was a principle witness in the case of John Smith a Senator from the State of Ohio, on the investigation of whose account I was compelled to take so active a part. Forbes also was at the Office, uncertain whether to press for an appointment at Plymouth, or to decline it— My Son John this Evening most unexpectedly returned here. He left Baltimore, this morning at three O’Clock, with his brother, in the Stage, through York and Lancaster, for Philadelphia; before daylight, and about seven miles on their way from Baltimore, they discovered that the baggage of all the passengers, being seven trunks, was lost from behind the Carriage— They turned back, and in a house near Baltimore found four of the trunks among which was George’s— Three of which one was John’s were not found. John finding himself stripped of all his cloathing, concluded to return here; for which he hired a Gig and driver at Baltimore— George after finding his trunk proceeded on his Journey to Philadelphia, where he will wait for his brother. Mrs Adams spent this Evening at Dr Thornton’s.

8. VII:Mr Rice, the Clergyman, who preached at the Capitol last Sunday came with Dr. Allison, Chaplain to the House of Representatives, to solicit my subscription for building a Baptist Church, in this City, near Commodore Porter’s house, Mrs. Adams procured a small supply of indispensable cloathing for John, and he took his second departure for Baltimore, at eleven O’Clock this Morning— I received a despatch from J. Forsyth, from which it appears probable that he has before this left Madrid, and is now at Paris waiting for Instructions— I sent it to the President’s, but met him returning from his ride on horseback and informed him of its contents— Dined at Commodore Rodger’s with a company of about twenty men. The Secretary and Commissioners of the Navy, General Brown, Coll. Wool, and several members of Congress were of the Company— Brown the Senator from Louisiana, and Sergeant member of the House from Philadelphia, who rode with me home— I found the company already assembled at my House for the weekly tea-party— About sixty persons came, rather more than the average number since it has become a regular company evening, without special invitations, except to strangers who visit us in the course of the week. There was music by the Ladies; and two or three Cotillions danced, one of the young Ladies playing the tune at the Piano.

9. VII: Received a Letter from my Son John at Baltimore, where upon his arrival last evening he found that his trunk had been recovered, uninjured, and unopened. Commodore Chauncey called at the Office, to recommend the appointment of a Consul at Port Mahon, Minorca, for the Balearic Islands, and upon his own claim for negotiating the last Treaty with Algiers, and for having given Passages, and even residence on board his Squadron, to Shaler the Consul General to Barbary, and others of the Consuls. E. Wyer paid one of his long visits at the Office. He is a gossip, whose occupation is to tell stale and insignificant news with an air of mystery. I called at the President’s and met Crawford there— The President is much dissatisfied with the proceedings of Mr Forsyth at Madrid; and directed a Meeting of the Members of the Administration at his house at One O’Clock to-morrow, to consider of the answers to be given to Mr Hyde de Neuville, the French Minister’s Letter of 29. January on the Baltimore piracies— After the Letter and my answer had been seen by all the Members of the Administration, the President thought upon
further reflection that it would be better for me to see De Neuville, and suggest to him verbally the objectionable character of some passages in his Letter, which he thought would induce him to take it back— As the relation of De Neuville with us has been of a very friendly character, and as he was induced at the President’s request to remain here this winter, after he had actually engaged his passage to France on a leave of absence; the President was very unwilling to assume with him a tone of asperity— This is at once mild and considerate. In the Evening, I attended with Mrs Adams the Drawing-Room at the President’s— I had Conversations there with F. Walker, a Senator from Georgia, about Forsyth’s despatches, and with R. M. Johnson of Kentucky about Duanes Letters— Walker has introduced into the Senate a Resolution, calling upon the President for further information relating to the Negotiation with Spain. I told him that the despatches received from Forsyth, and his Notes to the Spanish Minister of State had not given satisfaction to the President, and he thought they would if published give great dissatisfaction to the Country, and Mortification to Forsyth’s friends— He had therefore directed that they should be shewn to the Senators from Georgia, suggesting to them the consideration whether it would not be most advisable to forbear pressing the call for papers which could only be compiled with by making them public. Walker said that although Forsyth was one of the most intimate friends he had in the world; he could not possibly approve that part of his diplomatic correspondence which had been made public— That he would readily follow the course recommended by the President—he would call at the Department of State, and read the despatches; and would not call up his Resolution for the Present— Mr Poletica the Russian Minister was also very inquisitive concerning the despatches last received from Forsyth; and told me he had received himself Letters mentioning that he was on the point of leaving Madrid— I did not however think it proper to be communicative with him on this occasion, just at this time; nor to ask him to be more explicit— I told Coll. R. M. Johnson, what the President had said of Duane’s Letters and proposals; and asked him if was willing that the Letters should be shewn to the other Heads of Departments— Johnson said he should be willing, if there was reason to suppose the advice they should give, after the perusal, would change the President’s present opinion, and induce him to comply with Duane’s wishes— I told him I could not answer for the operation of the Letters upon other men’s minds, but I had no reason to suppose they would think differently from the President on this subject or advise him to a different course from that which he had determined to adopt— Johnson said if that that was the case, he did not wish that the other Heads of Departments should see the Letters; but he would call at my house, and take them back— I mentioned to him the President’s idea, of employing judge Todd’sson, upon the agency to Venezuela which he much approved.— Home from the President’s about ten.

10. VI:30. There was a fall of Snow, which turned to Hail and Sleet, which began soon after Sunrise this morning and continued till Night. In the Evening it held up— The ground was entirely covered with Snow, perhaps four inches deep, but there was not much of a Storm. I took Charles to school in the Carriage, and paid several visits— Attended the Cabinet Meeting at the President’s at One O’Clock— The Secretaries of the Treasury, War, and Navy were there— The Attorney General, Wirt, absent— The question was what should be done, with the French Minister, Hyde de Neuville’s Letter of 29 January— It was unanimously concluded most expedient that I should see and converse with him upon it— As to the part which contains a menace of measures to be taken by France; as I was satisfied he had no authority from his Government, for using it; I was persuaded he would upon being asked what he meant by it, explain it away— But I asked what I should say to the other part of his Letter, which was a request that the Attorney General of the United States should be employed to manage a prosecution of Chace, the Captain of one of the Baltimore Pirate-Privateers, for robberies and outrages committed against certain French vessels and property— There was a question whether it could be required of the Attorney-General as a part of his Official duty; and agreed that it could not— The necessity for supplementary aid to the prosecution, was inferred from what was stated to be the notorious incompetency of the District Attorney, Glenn for the Office of public Prosecutor— Crawford was very decided, and somewhat earnest
for his removal, but there was found to be great difficulty in fixing upon a person more competent, and willing to accept the Office for his successor— It would indeed be a very invidious act to remove him upon such grounds and the idea was soon given up— The question about employing the Attorney-General rests upon the mode of compensating him for the service; there being no fund appropriated for it— He was actually employed in one of the Portuguese cases last Winter, and obtained for it, by direction of the President a fee of 1500 dollars— It was paid partly from a fund at the disposal of the Treasury Department, and the rest from the Contingent fund for foreign intercourse— But some of the Members of the House of Representatives having heard of it, made it the subject of a formal enquiry; upon which a Committee is at this time occupied. The President and all the members of the Administration were of opinion that it would be proper to employ the Attorney General to assist in the prosecution, and that his fee might be paid from the contingent fund for foreign intercourse, unless there should be some vote of disapprobation in Congress upon the application of part of the fund to a similar payment before. I was directed therefore to say to Mr De Neuville, that if the Attorney-General could without inconvenience be employed, he would be, but that no promise to that effect could be given. Something was said about Forsyth’s despatches, and I was directed to write to him immediately, giving him permission to return to the United States— The President was inclined to do more, and to express his positive disapprobation of Forsyth’s conduct, and of the style of his official Notes at Madrid— I thought it would be sufficient to recall him without any mark of approbation of his conduct; and although it is impossible to justify the style that he has used, and still less the determination which he took of his own head, to leave Spain without instructions from his Government, yet great allowances were to be made for the provocation under which he had acted. Crawford said he regretted that some disapprobation had not been made known to Forsyth, when the first of his offensive Notes had been communicated here— The object of this remark was to transfer the blame of Forsyth’s conduct to me, but I took no notice of it— Forsyth was appointed to that mission by Crawford’s influence, strongly against my inclination— He had neither the experience, nor the prudence, nor the sincerity, nor the delicacy of sentiment, suited for such a Station. But it suited Crawford’s views that Forsyth should be pushed forward, and he was so— Calhoun said that Forsyth’s diplomatic Notes, were exactly like his speeches in Congress—ironical—that he gave more personal offence to his opponents by indulging himself in that style, than any other member, with whom he ever sat in a deliberative assembly— Now the great faults of Forsyth at Madrid, have been indiscretion and indecorum; faults quite sufficient to shew that he was not qualified for the Office of a public Minister, on a highly critical mission, but which ought not to be severely punished by those who appointed him knowing his character— The meeting broke up about four O’Clock, and I sent a Note to the French Minister requesting him to call at my Office at one to-morrow. I rode home, the Snow still continuing to fall. Evening in my chamber, reading newspapers and writing arrears of Journal.

11. VII:Mr Hersant, one of the persons, attached to the French Legation, came this morning, with a request that I would receive him at a different hour from that which I had appointed; to which I agreed, and named four, instead of one— I went up to the Capitol and heard Mr King in the Senate, upon what is called the Missouri question— He had been speaking perhaps an hour before I went in and heard him about an hour. His manner is dignified, grave, earnest, but not rapid or vehement. There was nothing new in his argument; but he unravelled with ingenious and subtle analysis, many of the sophistical issues of the Slave-holders— He laid down the position of the natural liberty of man, and its incompatibility with Slavery in any shape; he also questioned the Constitutional right of the President and the Senate, to make the Louisiana Treaty; but he did not dwell upon those points nor draw the consequences from them, which I should think important in speaking to that subject. He spoke however with great power, and the great Slave-holders in the house gnawed their lips, and clenched their fists as they heard him— The Senate adjourned to Monday, immediately after he finished, and I went into the House of Representatives, where I found R. C. Anderson of Kentucky speaking upon the same subject, but the other side of the question— He speaks with fluency, as do almost all the members of Congress— This facility is one of the greatest impediments to our Legislation. In the British Parliament there are about ten or twelve Ministerial Speakers, and as many on the Opposition side who perform almost all the debating part of deliberation. There are never more than two or three long speeches on each side, and the question
is always taken before the House adjourns— Here a single question is sometimes debated three weeks, and Members make speeches three days long— After the adjournment I went to my Office, where Mr Hyde de Neuville the French Minister came according to appointment at four O’Clock. I had only the translation of his Letter of 29. January, and asked him for an explanation of those passages which threatened certain measures to be taken by France, unless the Baltimore piracies should be effectually suppressed by ourselves— He disclaimed any intention of threatening at-all; and as invariably happens, when men attempt to maintain by argument that which they have said or written without Consideration, he was obliged to prevaricate in order to explain away his own meaning— He spoke no more of what France had deferred to do, from motives of Confidence, in us, but must do, unless we should, and that, soon, make it unnecessary; but of his private opinion, that she ought to do it, and the thing was no more a general search of suspected or signalised vessels, under our flag, but merely Instructions to her naval Officers, such as we had given to those of our Ships of War— I told him that as it had the appearance of a menace, I had been under the necessity of asking an explanation, and had at first put that request in writing— But as this would necessarily have led to a discussion, which it might also have been necessary to make public, the President had thought it best I should see him; and ask the explanation verbally. I had sent all his former communications on the Baltimore piracies to the Committee of the House of Representatives on foreign relations, who had that subject before them, and they had been most earnestly urged to propose to Congress a revisal of the Law, and other measures to suppress that abomination—but I had not sent them this last Letter, because it would certainly have had with them a counteracting tendency and their first question would have been what answer had been given to it— As I had always transacted business with him rather on terms of individual friendship than in diplomatic formality, I wished him to let me send him back this note, rather than enter into a written correspondence to explain it— He was exceedingly unwilling to do either, and asked a day or two for reflection to which I assented. He said it was derogatory to the character of a Minister to take back a Note once sent—that on returning home he would re-examine his note, and would give me any explanation of it to shew that he intended no menace by it. That as I had sent his other Notes on the subject to the Committee, he was satisfied, and that if the Commanders of French vessels of War, were authorised to do as much and no more than our own Officers had been instructed to do for the suppression of the Slave-trade, that though useful might be attended with inconveniences and abuses— He asked if the Attorney-General would be directed to manage the prosecutions at Baltimore against the piracies committed upon French vessels— I told him that would depend upon circumstances: intimated to him the objection that had been made to the employment of him in similar cases before, and said that in the event of the entire removal of that objection, the President would readily engage him to attend in the French cases at Baltimore— We attended an Evening party at Mr Calhoun’s, and heard of nothing but the Missouri question, and Mr King’s Speeches— The Slave-holders cannot hear of them without being seized with cramps— They call them seditious and inflammatory, when their greatest real defect is their timidity. Never since human sentiments and human conduct were influenced by human speech, was there a theme for eloquence, like the free side of this question now before the Congress of this Union— By what fatality does it happen that all the most eloquent Orators of the Body are on its slavish side— There is a great mass of cool judgment and plain sense on the side of Freedom and humanity; but the ardent Spirits, and Passions, are on the side of oppression— Oh! if but one man could arise with a Genius capable of comprehending, a heart capable of supporting and an utterance capable of communicating those eternal truths that belong to this question, to lay bare in all its nakedness that outrage upon the goodness of God, human Slavery, now is the time, and this is the occasion upon which such a man would perform the duties of an Angel upon Earth.

12. VI:15.Mr Turrell Tufts a distant relation of mine called this morning at my house— He was for some years the Consul of the United States at Surinam, and has lately returned from that Country— He is a man, somewhat uncouth in his personal appearance, and eccentric in his character. He did not tell me the object of his visit here at this time, but he recommended Thomas Trask, for the appointment of Consul or Commercial Agent at Surinam. Dr Kent a member of Congress from Maryland was also here, to ask recommendations for a Son of the
late Mr Stoddert— Andrew Mitchell a Clerk in the Treasury Department came to the Office, with a Letter from W. Davis Robinson, now at New-York, soliciting employment as an Agent in South-America— In this Letter he avows his connection with Devereux, and his anxiety to extricate himself from it. My duty is only to lay all such applications before the President for his decision. J. B. Colvin, one of the Clerks in the Department of State, spoke to me this day about certain attacks upon him in the newspapers— He has talents for the despatch of business, beyond any other man in the department, excepting Bailey, and having been many years Editor of a Newspaper he has much knowledge of the general politics of the Country, and writes in a handsome and forcible style— But his life has been dissipated and wasteful—charges of a heinous complection are in circulation against his moral character— A general opinion prevails that he is utterly unprincipled, and with abilities far above his station which he holds, he is almost entirely destitute of friends— He was appointed a Clerk in the Department of State by Robert Smith in 1809. and when Smith went out of Office and quarreled with Madison, Colvin gave him the coup de grace, by publishing that he had been the writer of some of Smith’s most important State Papers— This disclosure was fatal to Smith, but it gave no favourable opinion of Colvin’s trust-worthiness to the Public— While Mr Monroe was Secretary of State, he always distrusted Colvin, and Brent has told me that Colvin wrote much in opposition to Mr Monroe’s election to the Presidency. After I came into the Department of State, I had no intercourse with Colvin, but such as arose necessarily from his situation as Clerk in the Department, for about a year— He was said to be the Editor of the Washington City Gazette, which was in sharp opposition to Mr Monroe’s administration, and was considered as entirely subservient to Mr Clay— In the Summer of 1818. There appeared in the National Register, an Octavo weekly paper published at Georgetown, a panegyrical character of J. Q. Adams under the title of American Gallery of Portraits N. 1.— There has been no N. 2. and soon after the publication of the piece I learnt with surprize that Colvin was the author of it. The Washington Gazette continued an opposition paper through more feebly supported all the last Session of Congress, and part of last Summer— But at the last Session the two Houses of Congress chose by ballot printers for the work of Congress, Gales and Seaton Editors of the National Intelligencer, were almost unanimously chosen, and Elliot, Editor of the Washington Gazette though a Candidate was not supported by Mr Clay or his friends. From that time Clay has been out of favour with the Washington Gazette; but I was out of its flavour too till the last Autumn— The National Register after changing hands several times was purchased by Elliot; and soon after I returned here last October, I found frequent Editorial Articles in the Washington Gazette defensive against attacks in other papers upon me, and otherwise flattering to me, and also frequent bitter attacks upon Clay— So long as Colvin had been considered the Editor of a Paper devoted to Clay, and hostile to me, I had taken no notice of it, at-all. When I found he had become my encomiast, I desired Mr Brent to give him a hint, that if he was Editor of a Newspaper and was disposed to vindicate against unjust aspersions the general course of Mr. Monroe’s Administration, I should be well pleased with it; but that although duly sensible to his good opinion, I wished him to abstain entirely from publications of personal commendation upon me— Early after the commencement of the present Session of Congress, Colvin told me, that he had undertaken to be the Editor of the Washington City Gazette for this Winter, to prevent its falling into bad hands; and to assist the Printer, Elliot, who was poor, and had a family to maintain— But that he received no compensation for it, whatever. The management of the paper has thus been in a manner placed entirely placed at my disposal, but I have made no use of the power— It has not been discreetly managed, but has defended the administration, with considerable ability, and has particularly repelled several indignant assaults upon me— It has been beyond necessity and propriety severe, and even abusive upon Clay— And it has courted the hostility of several Newspapers of some influence some of them without apparent motive— It has carried on a spirited War with the Aurora of Philadelphia, the most furious, and yet most powerful of the Prints in opposition, and with the Kentucky Reporter, which is the creature of Clay—and it has occasionally assailed other popular Papers, of opposition Politicks or doubtful
complection, partly I suppose to push the paper into notice— When Colvin first threw down the gauntlet to defy the Aurora, Duane, its Editor blustered and bullied, declaring that he would have no altercation with the subalterns of the Department of State, but would carry the War, directly to Head Quarters— For nearly two years before, there was no species of vilification but the Aurora had been pouring forth upon me, without intermission. Colvin however by continuing his attacks on Duane, and by touching his sore parts soon provoked him to a frenzy, and Duane suddenly ceasing all abuse upon me, is now constantly raving with personalities upon Colvin— In the mean time Duane has been, by means of his correspondence with Coll. R. M. Johnson, hoisting the white flag to the President and to me. He is continually reproaching Colvin with his dissolute private life, and with his treachery to Robert Smith— This last Article was that upon which Colvin spoke to me this day— He said he hoped I did not give credit to Duane’s aspersions upon him. I told him that knowing at least nine tenths of everything published by Duane against myself was willful falsehood I generally inferred that what he said of others whom he wished to injure was of the same character. I gave no credit therefore to his abuse of any man. That as to Colvin’s conduct towards Robert Smith: I had known of it only what had been made public— I had very high ideas of the confidence between man and man—and if Smith had confidentially employed him to write diplomatic papers for him, the provocation must be great indeed which could justify him in divulging the fact, at a time and in a manner, which might must necessarily injure Smith in the public opinion more than from the intrinsic nature of the transaction, it ought— He said the facts had never been correctly known to the Public— That it was not Robert Smith, but Mr Madison, who had brought him into this Department— That Robert Smith, instead of bringing him into the Department had attempted to put him out of it, in order to introduce the late Dr Blake in his stead. That there had been nothing particularly confidential in Smith’s employing him to write papers for him. That the first time he had engaged him to answer a Letter of General Turreau’s, he had said to him—come, you may now try your hand at a diplomatic note. Colvin said he had really never valued himself much upon his Style, and should never have revealed to the world that he had written R. Smith’s papers, if Smith had not, besides treating him very ill made his unprincipled attack upon Mr Madison, whom Colvin considered as his benefactor— As to Duane, he said there had been a time when he had been very intimate with him. He had now a large bundle of Letters from him. That he had broken off all intercourse with him upon a proposition which Duane had made to him which had convinced him that Duane was an unprincipled scoundrel— It was that he Colvin should write in a disguised hand, an anonymous Letter to Mr Madison, to urge him to remove Gideon Granger from the Office of Post-Master General for propagating false and scandalous Stories, affecting the character of Mrs Madison— There was something so infamous in the part which Duane thus wanted him to perform, that the proposal of it had disgusted him, to the degree that he had resolved to hold no further intercourse with him— True it was however that Granger had circulated dishonourable tales about Mrs Madison; and for two or three years before he was removed from the Post-Office he had been continually caballing with Members of Congress against Mr Madison— He had lived on the Capitol-Hill; and his house was a seat of perpetual caucusing of malcontent members. Dr Leib then a Senator from Pennsylvania was one of them; and Granger appointed him Postmaster at Philadelphia; contrary to an express injunction from Mr Madison to appoint another man— Now Colvin knows nothing of Duane’s proposals to surrender, and fancies he is rendering me an important service by undertaking my defence against Duane; while Duane fancies that Mr Monroe will be glad to buy off his foulness of mouth, with a South-American agency— As I was returning home, I overtook and walked with Mr Macon, Senator from North-Carolina— Evening at home—

13. VI:15. Attended the divine Service at the Capitol and heard Mr Edward Everett, the Professor of the Greek language, at Harvard University; a young man of shining talents and of illustrious promise. His text was from 1. Cor: 7.29. “Brethren, the time is short”—and it was without comparison the most splendid composition as a Sermon that I ever heard delivered. He had preached it last Sunday Evening wheremySons had heard him; and George had written to me that it was the finest Sermon he had ever heard, and foretelling that he would preach it again here. Hacknied as this subject, the shortness of time is, I never before saw so forcibly exemplified the truth, that nothing is stale or trite in the hands of Genius— His composition is more rich, more varied, more copious more magnificent than was that of Buckminster— There were passages that reminded me perhaps too much of Massillon: but the whole Sermon was equal to any of the best that Massillon ever wrote— It abounded in splendid imagery, in deep pathos, in cutting Satire, in profound reflections of morals, in coruscations of wit—in thunderbolts of feeling— His manner of speaking was slow, and his articulation distinct, perhaps to excess— There
was some want of simplicity, both in the matter and manner— A still greater defect was a want of unity in his subject— He gave as one Sermon a cento of Extracts from two or more— There was a description of the destructive operations of Time, absolutely terrific—and a portrait of blessings and future glories of this Country, wrought up like a work of enchantment— The house was full but not crowded. The New England hearers were rapt into enthusiasm. Mr King told me he had never heard anything like it. The Southern auditors approved more coolly. Mr Clay with whom I walked after the Service to call upon Chief Justice Marshall, told me that he although Everett had a fine fancy, and a chaste Style of composition, his manner was too theatrical, and he liked Mr Holley’s manner better— Clay started however immediately to the Missouri question, yet in debate before both houses of Congress, and alluding to a strange Scene at Richmond Virginia last Wednesday Evening, said it was a shocking thing to think of; but he had not a doubt that within five years from this time, the Union would be divided into three distinct confederacies— I did not incline to discuss this subject with him— We found Judges Livingston and Story with the Chief Justice. I came home for a moment, after meeting successively in the avenue John Sergeant and Ingersoll— Mr Otis had invited me to go and dine with him at Crawford’s in Georgetown, and I walked there— Mr King, Judge Story, Mr Everett, and Mr Webster of Boston formed the party, with Mrs Otis, who is in deep mourning for a daughter whom she has lost since she has now been here— The party was quite social, and the Missouri subject was very freely canvassed— King has made a desperate plunge into it, and has thrown his last stake upon the card— It agitates him accordingly with deep and vehement emotion— He has however great self controul; cool judgment: and Spirit breaking experience. There was difference enough of opinion between us, to occasion much, though no angry discussion. I sat with them till after dark, and then walking crossed the Bridge, and met near Poletica’s house my Carriage going for me— I called at Mr Fryes, and took up Mrs Adams with Mary Hellen and Charles who had all dined there.

14. VI:15.J. M. Forbes and Edward Wyer, were successively at the Office this morning. Both solicitors for Office as a source of subsistence, but with pretensions of very different merit. Forbes was two years since displaced from an agency at Copenhagen, by the suppression of its Salary— Wyer is Consul at Hamburg, and has left his Post to come and pass the Winter here in poaching for something better. A Mr Bostwick also came to the Office. I was at the President’s, and he desired me to see judge Todd, and enquire if his son would accept the agency to Venezuela— He also desired me to speak of it to Coll. R. M. Johnson—and inform him that W. Duane could of course not have the appointment; and to let A. Mitchell know the same thing with regard to W. D. Robinson’s application. Mr and Mrs W. S. Smith spent the Evening here.

15. VI:30.Robert Raimond Reid, a member of the House of Representatives from Georgia came and introduced to me a Dr Waring of Savannah now on a visit to this place— C. J. Ingersoll and R. Peters junr. of Philadelphia, called on me at the Office. They are here in attendance on the Supreme Court of the United States which is in Session— The President called at the Office— Mrs Adams had her weekly Evening tea-party, attended by about sixty persons, among whom several of the Judges of the Supreme Court, and several other Strangers. John Labouchere, the son of my old acquaintance at Amsterdam and elsewhere; and nephew of Alexander Baring was here, with a young man named Insinger, also from Amsterdam. I spoke to Judge Todd of the President’s intention to offer the agency to Venezuela to his Son, and enquired whether he would accept it— He said he had no doubt that he would, and promised to call upon me to-morrow Morning for further conversation concerning it.

16. VI:30.Judge Todd called this Morning at my house and had some further conversation with me respecting the appointment of his Son as agent to Venezuela— He enquired what would be the compensation, and how long it was to be expected the agency would continue, and what would be its principal objects— I answered him as far as I was authorised by the intentions disclosed heretofore by the President, and premised to take immediately his directions with regard to the remainder. Coll. R. M. Johnson also came and two I returned to him Duane’s two Letters. The Coll. was uneasy at being under the necessity of returning a negative answer to both Duane’s applications, and asked whether he might not hold out to him an expectation of being employed hereafter if an opening should present itself for an agency in Mexico. I told
him I thought it would be most candidate with Duane to hold out no expectation to him whatever. The same objection against him now existing in the Presidents mind, would probably continue to exist namely that the appointment to an office of considerable emolument and of high confidential trust of the Editor of a Newspaper, the daily columns of which had for years been filled with imputations of the grossest kind both upon the capacity and integrity of the President and every member of his Administration would be generally disgusting to the Public, who would take it as a mere buying up of an enemy— Duane talked of the President’s obligations to him, which the President altogether denied. Duane would not pretend I was under obligations to him— I owed him neither love nor fear— But I should not stand in his way. Johnson said Duane was a man of great information and considerable talents, but without judgment—a proof of which, was in his complaints against the President, in the very Letter by which he was soliciting favours from him. He asked whether, if he should obtain recommendations of Duane from the two Senators from Pennsylvania, I thought they would influence the President in his favour. I said I could not tell—perhaps they might— At least I was sure the President would give all due consideration to any recommendation from the Pennsylvania Senators— How far it might be advisable to apply to the Pennsylvania Senators, for their recommendation I was sure he would duly consider. I doubted whether they would give it— At least two years ago, it was at the most earnest and vehement intreaty of the Pennsylvania Senators and most particularly of Mr Roberts that the Aurora was dismissed from the publication of the United States Laws. Roberts then reasoned the affair over both with the President and with me; and his principal argument was the indecency of continuing public patronage to a Printer whose papers were teeming with the most willful and malicious Slander against the President, his Administration and all its friends— Now Duane having a daily newspaper to work with; and being in the constant habit of venting all his private resentments and all his splenetic humours in his paper, against whoever displeased him, it might be no very agreeable thing to the Senators of Pennsylvania to be asked in his favour, for that which they could neither honestly grant, nor safely refuse— When compliance would only be to promote the views of a common defamer, and refusal would expose them to all his malevolence— Johnson said he should duly consider all this; and added that he had also been requested to recommend Dr Thornton for a mission to South-America, and Dr. Allison, to succeed him as superintendent of the Patent Office—Johnson is a man who can refuse no favor to any person— He would recommend ten persons for one and the same place, rather than say no, to any one of them— I told him of the President’s intention to appoint judge Todd’s son to go to Venezuela, with which he was very well pleased. The President had already spoken if it to him— Mr Eddy one of the Members of the House of Representatives from Rhode-Island, came to make complaint against Asher Robbins, District Attorney of the United States, and Charles Collins, Collector of the Port of Bristol in that State; for connivence at, and participation in the African Slave-trade. He said that the fact was notorious as daylight that vessels were constantly fitted out and despatched from Bristol for the Guinea trade. That Collins had a plantation in the Island of Cuba which he had lately stocked with negroes, and where he had spent the last Winter— That Robbins during the late War with Great-Britain had made a trade of the Laws against the trading intercourse with the enemy— That John Carlile of Providence, had told him that he had paid Robbins 500 dollars for discontinuing a prosecution which as District Attorney he had commenced against a man for trading with the enemy, contrary to Law— That he had told him William Blodget had as agent for several such foul traders paid Robbins from five to eight hundred dollars each, for discontinuing several prosecutions against them. And he said that now, Robbins was carrying on the same kind of traffic in the Laws against the Slave trade— Eddy said that it was extremely disagreeable to him, to feel himself under an obligation of duty to give this information; but as no one else would do it, he had resolved that the Session of Congress should not pass over leaving the President uninformed of these flagrant violations of the Laws— He further referred me to Mr Burrill the Senator for a confirmation of the facts— He said something of a Mr Pitman as a suitable person for the appointment of District Attorney in place of Robbins— I told him I would make report of his information to the President, and let him know the result— At the Office, Manuel Torres the agent from Venezuela came and told me that his Negotiation with the Bank of the United States for money had not succeeded, and he therefore now came for a supply of arms from the Government. I desired him to make the application in writing, and promised to lay it before the President— He shewed me the Letters which had passed between him and L. Cheves, the President of the Bank, with whom he professed to be entirely satisfied. But the main object of Torres in this visit manifestly was to discredit William D. Robinson. He had already written me a Letter disclaiming a publication in the Washington City Gazette of 6. December last, and of which he now told me that Robinson was the author— He said that Robinson while in England had
fastened himself upon General Devereux, and had persuaded him to transcend his instructions and authority from the Government of Venezuela in a manner which would certainly be disapproved. He had induced him to delay and to change his plan of operations and to undertake a foolish expedition against Cuba and Mexico, for which he had no sort of authority, and which if pursued would certainly fail. Robinson was very ardent in the Patriot cause, and he Torres was very grateful to him for his zeal; but he was very well known, and not much esteemed in Venezuela. Before the commencement of the Revolution there he had been employed as a spy by the Spanish Government, and in consequence of it had now claims on the Government of Spain. He had induced Devereux in England to issue Commissions for Officers in the name of the Government of Venezuela, and to entrust him with blank Commissions of the same kind to be sold in this Country; and Robinson had been making attempts to put some of them off, here and at New-York. But all this was unauthorized and would undoubtedly be disapproved in Venezuela. The people there were not at all disposed to submit to the assumption of Sovereign and Independent authorities in their name by foreigners and especially by heretics— The English troops who had enlisted in their service would be well maintained and well paid for their services; but the assistance wanted of them was military and not political— They were soldiers, and not Sovereigns— The Venezuelan Government had already been disappointed by two English Agents, one of whom was named Hamilton, and who had failed in furnishing supplies of arms for which they had contracted, and been paid, and this was one principal cause of the necessity they were under of obtaining a supply in this Country— Much of this information of Torres had already been given in Duane’s Letters to R. M. Johnson, and the coincidences shews where Duane obtained it, as well as the confidential intimacy of Duane, both with Torres, and with Robinson— It discloses also the management of Robinson here as Devereux’s agent, while he is soliciting the agency from the United States to Venezuela— N. Silsbee, T. Newton, chairman of the Committee of Commerce H.R. Baron Stackelberg and Dr Thornton were also this morning at the Office, and absorbed the day— We spent the Evening with a party at Mr Bulfinch’s.

17. VII:Dr Thornton came again to the Office, to re-urge his pretensions for appointment as agent of the United States to Venezuela, or any other part of South-America. Of all the official duties of my Station, there is none that tries the temper so severely as that of conflicting with the stubborn perseverance of unsuccessful candidates for office. To persist in reiterated refusal without ever falling into harshness of manner, is a labour more than Herculean— An unprovocable temper is the first of qualities to be prayed for, in the discharge of these duties— The doctor will not receive this appointment, and this day came to insist upon his claims to it; to hint at the multitude of powerful friends who would intercede for him; among whom he expected would be many of the Senators, and to enquire what were the Reasons why he should not be appointed. I told him that as he had always been a very ardent South-American Patriot, perhaps the President might think a person more cool, would suit better for the impartial observation necessary to such an agency— He thought that very strange; for in his opinion, it was precisely that which made him peculiarly fit for the Agency— I was at the President’s, and reported to him the substance of Judge Todd’s conversation respecting the appointment of his Son; and Mr Eddy’s charges against Robbins the District Attorney in Rhode-Island, and Collins the Collector at Bristol in the same State— The President said he would fix the Compensation of the Agents to South-America, on a par with those allowed by Law to Chargés d’Affaires—a Salary at the rate of 4500 dollars a year, and in lieu of outfit, a passage in a public vessel, and reasonable necessary travelling expences— He said he had thoughts of appointing W. P. Van Ness, now District Judge of the Southern District of New-York, to go as agent to Buenos-Ayres, authorizing Prevost who is now there to return as he wishes to Chili— As to the charges against Robbins and Collins he requested me to call on the Senators, and members of the House from Rhode-Island, and arrange with them the manner of calling upon those persons to vindicate their characters or to institute an enquiry into the facts, which is now indispensably necessary. With regard to Dr Thornton, the appointment of him was out of the question. It was not compatible with the courtesy of social life to tell him the real reason why which was that the Doctor, with great learning, ingenuity, and good-humour, wanted discretion, a quality quite indispensable
for these agencies.— We had company to dinner— Messrs. Gaillard, President pro tempore of the Senate, Horsey, and Johnson of Louisiana, Senators, Stevenson Archer, Baldwin, Silsbee, Street and Whitman of the House of Representatives, R. J. Meigs, Post-master General, Professor Everett, General Harper, Genl Swartwout. Coll. Wool, Genl. P. B. Porter, C. J. Ingersoll, R. Peters junr.D. WebsterW. S. Smith, and Horace Gray— There had been invited the Senators John Elliot of Georgia, William Hunter of Rhode-Island and William Smith of South-Carolina, who declined the invitation. Generals Brown and CadwaladerColl. Bomford, Commodores Chauncey and Decatur, Captain Biddle, H. W. Edwards and James Pindall, members of the House, J. H. Read of S. Carolina, Insinger and Labouchere, who sent excuses, from indisposition or previous engagement— The dinner was agreeable, but short, all the company being engaged at the Ball at Commodore Decatur’s, which we also attended— There were between three and four hundred persons present; every member of both houses of Congress, and all the principal inhabitants of Washington having received invitations. It was said to be the most splendid party ever given at this place. We came home before Midnight.

18. VII: I went up this morning to the Capitol, to converse with the members of Congress from Rhode-Island, concerning the charges against the District Attorney Robbins, and the collector of Bristol, Collins. In the Senate I spoke to Mr Burrill and Mr Hunter, both of whom spoke of it as a very unpleasant subject. Burrill to whom Eddy had referred me as being acquainted with the material facts, said he had no desire to give testimony in the case, but that from various circumstances which had come to his knowledge, he believed the facts charged by Mr Eddy against Robbins were true— The Slave-trade carried on by vessels fitted out from Bristol was perfectly notorious, and the Merchants at Providence were obliged to give higher wages to Seamen in their ordinary traffic, because they were told and knew that such high wages could always be obtained by the Sailors, by entering for the Guineamen at Bristol. It was impossible that this should be unknown to the Collector of the Port— Yet Burrill said he knew nothing to which he could positively testify against Collins. Hunter was yet more reluctant, being a Townsman of Robbins who resides at Newport, and a brother practitioner at the Bar. He said he had often heard rumours and surmises derogatory to the character of Robbins, but knew nothing against him to which he could testify— He would not attempt to screen him from enquiry or from punishment if he was guilty, but wished he might not be dismissed without having a previous opportunity of defending himself. He wished also if Robbins should be removed that the Delegation might be consulted, upon the appointment of his Successor— He knew that judge Story favoured the appointment of Mr Pitman, but he hoped it would be another person— In the House of Representatives, Mr Hazard was quite displeased at this complaint; said he was a friend of Robbins who was a man of talents and of estimable character in private life— There were many rumours unfavourable to his conduct as a public officer in circulation— What truth there was in them he could not tell; he wished not to interfere between Robbins, and the course of Justice; if he had been guilty, let him be dismissed; but at least his successor should be a Newport man. Perhaps the Attorney-General of the State— Almost all the best Offices both of the State Government and of the Union, in Rhode Island were held at Providence; and Newport ought to have her share— What he hoped especially was that Robbins should be informed of the charges against him, and have the opportunity to repel them, which I told him was the Presidents full determination— I finished by speaking of this matter again to Mr Eddy. He seemed mortified to find himself alone in an accusation the cause for which was so notorious that he was unquestionably convinced it was as well known to every one of his associates, as to himself. I believe there is nothing so difficult as to detect and punish a public Officer for venality and corruption— I have not a scintillation of a doubt that both these men, Robbins and Collins, are guilty of Slave-trading or connivence at it. But informing is always an invidious task; and generally a very dangerous one; for when a man becomes an accuser, and fails of convicting the person accused even though really guilty, the charge recoils upon himself, and he incurs the odium of passing for a defamer; instead of obtaining credit as a terror to evil-doers— While in the House of Representatives, I heard Mr Lowndes speak about two hours upon the Missouri Slave Question. The House adjourned about three O’Clock, and I went to the President’s and gave him the substance of my Conversations with the Rhode-Island members. Here the matter rests for the present— Evening at home.

19. VI:Cardelli called this morning, to tell me that having finished his busts of Mr Jefferson, Mr Madison, and the President, he wished now to make casts of them for sale— Our Laws of Copyright do not expend to works of Sculpture, and I had promised Cardelli to put him in the way, as far as I could, of obtaining an Act of Congress
for that purpose— He said there had been no copy-right for Sculptors in England, till a few years ago, when Nollekens had obtained one— I advised him to go to the Office of the Department of State, and ask Mr Brent, to look up that Act in the British Statutes at Large. He soon came back with the Book, containing the Act which is of June 1798. I advised him to take it to Mr Clay, the Speaker of the House of Representatives, and shew it to him, requesting his Counsel and assistance to obtain a similar Act here— I called at the President’s and mentioned to him the Letters received near a month since from the Governor of Georgia— He said he should not communicate the documents against Mitchell to Congress at present; but Mr Calhoun the Secretary at War, would send a copy of them to Mitchell himself, and let him know that the matter must be duly investigated— A copy of this Letter of Mr Calhoun’s should be furnished to me to be transmitted to the Governor of Georgia, with a request that he would transmit here any further testimony which may serve to ascertain the facts of the complaint against Mitchell— I read to the President, Mr H. Middleton’s answer, accepting the proposal of an appointment as Minister Plenipotentiary to Russia— Middleton intimates a wish that the mission may not be of long duration; on account of the inaptitude of the Country to furnish the means of education for his younger children— The President appeared to consider it as a claim to an appointment elsewhere after a short probation in Russia, and remarked that no encouragement to such an expectation could be given to Mr Middleton— Mr Forsyth and he, being both from the Southern Section of the Union, if any vacancies should soon occur in the other foreign Missions, it would be necessary to fill up the appointments from other quarters— I dined with a small party of Gentlemen at Mr Lowndes’s. Hopkinson was there—and Garnett a Virginian member of the House; and Mr Gaston, formerly a member of the House from North-Carolina; but now here as a lawyer, attending the Supreme Court— From Mr Lowndes’s, I went with Mrs Adams to Mr Hyde de Neuville’s weekly Evening party; and after a game of Chess there with Mr Tucker the Treasurer, to a Ball at Mr Gales’s. There I danced a Country dance with Mrs Seaton— My first dancing since the Ball at Ghent.

20. VII: Heard at the Capitol a preacher by the name of Russell, in no wise qualified to fill the place occupied last Sunday by Edward Everett. He was of the common-place class of Speakers, whose discourses leave no traces upon the memory. After the service was finished I paid visits to several of the judges, but only saw judge Johnson, who told me he was engaged in drawing up a Bankrupt Act upon an entire new plan—to have neither Commissioners of Bankruptcy nor Assignees, but to allot to the District Judge the duties of the former, and to a single trustee those of the latter. I also called and visited R. Peters junr.Captain Biddle, Cadwalader and Hopkinson were not at home. I met there General Bloomfield, who with many others is much alarmed at the dissensions which have arisen in the Nation and in Congress from the Missouri or Slave question. The territory of Missouri is a part of the Louisiana cession. At the Session of Congress before last, a Bill was introduced for enabling its inhabitants to form a State Constitution— There was then not time to pass the Bill, which was referred over, and brought forward again at the last Session. When it was under debate at the second reading in Committee of the whole, an amendment was proposed by Genl. James Tallmadge, seconded by John W. Taylor, both members from the State of New-York, making it one of the conditions of the admission of Missouri that the further introduction of Slavery should be prohibited, and that Slaves hereafter born there should be free at the age of 25. This amendment excited a very angry debate, but was adopted by the House, disagreed to by the Senate, and each house adhering to its views the Bill was lost between them. When the amendment was first presented, its importance and consequences were certainly foreseen by no one, not even by those who brought it forward. Its discussion disclosed a secret—it revealed the basis for a new organization of parties— Clay had been two years labouring, first upon South-American Patriotism, and then upon the Seminole War, first in defiance of Crawford and then as a subaltern to him, to get up a new party. In both instances he had failed— But here was a new party ready formed, but of no pleasing aspect ether to Clay of Crawford: terrible to the whole Union, but portentously terrible to the South—threatening in its progress the emancipation of all their Slaves; threatening in its immediate effect that Southern domination which has swayed the Union for the last twenty years, and threatening that political ascendancy of Virginia, upon which Clay and Crawford both had fastened their
principal hopes of personal aggrandizement. The failure of the Bill, and the attempt to exclude Slavery from the future State of Missouri, produced great fermentation here, and in the Southern States, but particularly in Virginia. North and East it excited less feeling, but Mr King who had taken a considerable part in the debate at the last Session in Senate, in the course of the Summer set on foot and organized a concert of measures which have resulted in the struggle which now shakes the Union to its centre— Bloomfield, though a member from New-Jersey took at the last Session the Southern side of this question, and still adheres to it— But he says he received yesterday a Letter from a very sober and respectable neighbour of his, who asks him whether a civil War, would not be preferable to the extension of Slavery beyond the Mississippi.— This is a question between the rights of human nature and the Constitution of the United States— Probably both will suffer by the issue of the controversy— When I came home, I found here, Mr Van Brugh Livingston; a young man whom we had seen in England, but of whom I had lost the recollection— Evening at home.

21. VI:30.Judge Story called on me this morning with a Mr Tracy from Connecticut; who has a claim upon Spain. At the Office I had a succession of visitors, who absorbed the day— First Mr Bulfinch with Sully the Painter, who has brought here his Picture of the passage of the Delaware at Trenton, to be exhibited, and who requested me to go and see it. Then Mr Ingersoll— Captain O’Brien, the Sinbad of the day, with his rusty claim and H. M. Brackenridge who told me he wished to speak to me, about a pamphlet just published at Baltimore, attacking him and his Book, upon South-America— General Cocke, a member of the House of Representatives from Tennessee came to request the transmission of a Letter to G. W. Campbell— General Parker to make enquiries in behalf of certain claimants, and Mr Lowndes to ascertain the present state of the Negotiations with Spain, and the prospects of arrival here of a Minister from that Country— The succession of objects is so rapid and so various on these hurly-burly days that nothing durable is left upon the memory to record— We had a very small company to dinner— Daniel P. Cook—J. M. Forbes—Jos. Hopkinson, I. P. Hutchinson and W. S. Smith— We had also invited Captain Biddle, General Cadwalader, Mr and Mrs. Frye, C. J. Ingersoll, Labouchere, Sergeant, E. Wyer, and Mrs W. S. Smith, who by previous engagements or indisposition were prevented from coming— Hopkinson left us early, being engaged at a Ball at the Senator Brown’s.

22. VI:Cardelli was here this morning, having been advised by Mr Clay the Speaker to present a petition to Congress to pass an act, securing to him a property in his works of sculpture. He left with me a copy of the British Act of Parliament, and I promised to draw up a petition for him. Edward Wyer was at the Office. In the Evening I attended with Mrs Adams a subscription Ball; given upon the occasion of Washington’s Birth-day— The President and Mrs. Monroe, with their daughter Maria were there. It was in the house formerly occupied by the Spanish Minister Onis— The supper was served up about eleven O’Clock, and it was near Midnight when we came home.

23. VIII:A. Livermore and W. Plumer junr. members of the House of Representatives from New-Hampshire called upon me, and conversing on the Missouri-Slave question, which at this time agitates Congress and the Nation, asked my opinion of the propriety of agreeing to a compromise. The division in Congress and the Nation is nearly equal on both sides. The argument on the free side is the moral and political duty of preventing the extension of Slavery in the immense Country from the Mississippi river to the South-Sea. The argument on the Slave side, is that Congress have no power by the Constitution to prohibit Slavery in any State, and the zealots say not in any territory. The proposed compromise is to admit Missouri, and hereafter Arkansaw, as States without any restrictions upon them regarding Slavery; but to prohibit the future introduction of Slaves in all territories of the United States North of 36:30 Latitude— I told these Gentlemen, that my opinion was, the question could be settled no otherwise than by a compromise— The regulation, exclusion, or abolition of Slavery in the system of our Union, is among the Powers reserved to the People of the several States by their separate Governments; though I have no doubt that Congress have Constitutional powers to prohibit any internal traffic in Slaves, between one State and another— In the States where Slavery does not exist, neither Congress, nor the State Legislature nor the People have any rightful power to establish it. For the admission into the Union of a State where no Slavery exists, Congress may prescribe as a condition that Slavery shall never be established in it; as they have done, to the States of Ohio, Indiana, and Illinois; but where it exists, and where there are already Slaves in great numbers, as in Missouri and Arkansaw, the power of extirpating it is not given to Congress by the Constitution. To proscribe Slavery therefore in Missouri and Arkansaw I believe to be impracticable— But if a provision can be obtained excluding the introduction of Slaves into future territories, it will be a great and important point secured— I apprehend
however that Livermore and Plumer did not concur with me in opinion. Mr Roberts the Senator from Pennsylvania came to the Office with Captain Mulloney of Philadelphia, one of the general Candidates for Office, to whom no place with a good Salary could come amiss— Mr G. A. Otis, my sometime fellow passenger in the ship Washington, since which he has been unfortunate in commercial concerns, which has qualified him for any spare consulate abroad, present or to come, and in the meantime he is planting literary laurels, and has published at Philadelphia, a translation of the last of the Abbe de Pradt’s occasional Books on the Politics of Europe— Otis sent me one of his Books, and one for the President. He has now taken in hand Botta’s History of the American Revolution. Coll.
